reviewText:
Worms Revolution is one of the best Worms games available today.

I have been playing the Worms series since 1996, starting with Worms 1 on the Sega Saturn, so I am no stranger to this series.

If YOU are new to this series, or curious about the new additions, you are basically controlling a team of 1-8 worms (depending on game settings) in a battle to the death with some of the craziest weapons ever.
Weapons such as the Old Lady, Holy Hand Grenade, Super Sheep, Concrete Donkey, Bazooka,etc will be used as your team fights to the death in a turn-based battle with a time limit per turn and round.

You also get to use a variety of utilities to move around the map such as a Ninja Rope, Jetpack, Teleport, etc.

You have the option of making your own gamestyles with extensive customization settings, and this game also offers you the ability to make your own maps and play them online.

Some new features for this version from other Worms series include dynamic water, new interactive physics objects, and new weapons and utilities. Yes, the rope behaves differently, (think bungee cord) but once you get used to this change you will not want to go back to the stiff rope of past worms versions.

Now let's talk about system performance. Worms Revolution as you may of noticed, wants at least a dual core processor and a good video card. I have used a Pentium 4 3.60 Ghz in the past, and I was getting very playable framrates. A slow dual core seems to run this game very well paired with a good video card.

Yes, there are bugs in this game involving the new physics objects, and possibly annoying aspects relating to controls, but they are mostly minor. Voice Chat works well.

There is an active community online to this day, and adding friends to your friends list who play the game can help ensure full four player games often.
There is A Solo Campaign you need to play to earn coins to buy new classes of Worms. Your scores will also be recorded on Steam Leaderboards. This game has classes for your worms that helps them specialize in certain situations, such as stronger attacks from a Heavy, quicker movements with a Scout, or stronger tools with Scientists.

If you like the Worms series, or if this style of gameplay sounds even slightly interesting, I highly recommend you give this a look.

reviewText:
I remember playing Worms at a friend's place when it had just came out, and I had a lot of fun playing versus friends locally on just one PC.

Playing Worms Revolution brought back some of those memories, however I ended up playing Worms Revolution mainly as a single player game. Some people say that Worms is a multiplayer game, and you're supposed to play it with other players, but I see nothing wrong with playing Worms solely for the single player campaign. If you do, just think of Worms as a sort of puzzle game, and you will probably get a lot of enjoyment out of it. Some of the missions were frustatingly difficult thanks to the incredibly accurate AI, but that just made completing them feel that much more rewarding.

I played this game at the same time as I was playing Worms Clan Wars, and in my opinion Worms Revolution is by far the superior game. You can read my review of Worms Clan Wars here. I gave that game a negative review, not because I think it is a very bad game, but because this one is, in my opinion, so much better - and quite a bit cheaper as well.

Here's a few of the pros of Worms Revolution:
- The narrator (which is actually funny in this game, unlike that annoying woman in Worms Clan Wars)
- Plenty of challenging missions
- Interesting weapons (the only weapon that I missed was the Teleportation Gun from Clan Wars)
- Water physics

I can't really think of any big cons. The new worm-classes (Soldier, Scientist, Scout, Heavy) were a nice addition, although not really necessary in my opinion. It can also be a bit hard to find people online, especially if you want to play  a ranked match.

Still, I definitely recommend this game.

→　If you are the type of person who cares about achievements, note that there are several multiplayer achievements in this game, which can be a bit troublesome to get.

reviewText:
Review in Full (tl;dr version at the end):
The classic 2D Worms formula returns in Worms Revolution with a few significant changes. The new additions to the gameplay experience include four different classes, dynamic water, and physics objects, but none of the changes radically alter the familiar Worms experience.

The Worms Formula: For those who don't know, the meat of any Worms game is a turn-based strategy / shooter experience where you control a team of worms and move around a map (or utilize your worms' positions) in order to use weapons such as the explosive Sheep and the famous Holy Hand Grenade to eliminate enemy worms. All Worms games have no small measure of humor, as you'd expect upon hearing the premise, and the worms themselves contribute to the humor with their own gibberish vocalizations as they taunt enemy worms and panic if a stick of dynamite is set next to them. The weapons are of course part of the humor, and the Sheep and the Holy Hand Grenade aren't even the wackiest among them. At the core, however, the gameplay experience would make for a good time in multiplayer play even without the abundant humor.

New Additions (Classes, Dynamic Water, and Physics Objects):

Classes: The four classes of Worms include the basic soldier, the weaker but more nimble scout, the scientist, who provides a health bonus in turn for being weaker, and the slower but stronger and more resillient heavy.

Dynamic Water: The new dynamic water is an option utilized as a stage hazard and fired by three new weapons. Any worm who is knocked into dynamic water will take steady damage over time, instead of instantly drowning upon contact with normal water. Dynamic water utilizes real-world physics, sinking to the lowest area possible given its location and trajectory.

Physics Objects: Physics Objects are relatively normal objects scattered around every map. The twist, however, is that each object explodes when sufficiently damaged. In the process, they unleash fires, poison gas, or even dynamic water into the immediate vicinity.

Verdict and Recommendation: The wacky action of the Worms franchise is spruced up a bit by the new enhancements. None of the features radically alter the core experience, however, meaning that those who tried another Worms game but found it to be only interesting as a novelty or altogether unappealing need not apply. Worms Revolution is as good of a starting point as any for series newcomers, though, and those who enjoyed previous installments should find plenty to like here. If you are undecided, keep in mind that Worms Revolution is first-and-foremost a multiplayer experience, and the singleplayer campaign is decent, but it presents nothing to sway your decision.

tl;dr version: Worms 'Revolution' is no revolution, but the perennial Worms formula didn't need to be signficantly altered anyways.

reviewText:
HILARIOUSLY FUNNY GOOD TIMES!
Worms Revolution is a great game that is sure to have friendships on edge as players battle it out with crazy weaponry such as Cluster Bombs, Moles, Super Sheep, and the infamous Holy Hand Grenade. Players can choose between single player campaign, offline skirmishes, or online games with friends so there is never a shortage of carnage.

The campaign isn't very long, with around 32 missions (not including missions added from DLC) but you'll be laughing through-out the entire length of it. The AI isn't a push over either, if you're as bad as I am at least, and will definitely have you hiding in the caves if you're not careful. The narrator of the campaign is a bit...annoying to say the least, but the voices from the worms make up for it in the end.

Worms Revolution brings a new style of gameplay into the mix by adding classes to the classic worms game. Each class has it's own benefits to offer and can be the deciding factor on a major victory....or a horrible loss. The four classes available are Scout, Heavy, Soldier, and Scientist. Some of the benefits the classes offer are increased movement speed, increase jump height/distance, team-wide health regeneration, etc.

Physics objects are also a big game changer in Worms Revolution, adding objects that are highly volatile (more so than the common oil drum), or that contain dynamic liquid that you could use to literally wash away the competition. Unfortunately it seems that some of the classic weapons have been removed from the base game but others are offered in the available DLC.

All in all the game is loads of fun and it never seems to be the same game twice. I definitely recommend this game to anything looking for some casual fun offline, or for those who wish to duke it out with their friends in an epic online war and truly test friendships.

reviewText:
Imagine the successor to a good old Worms classic like Armageddon, or its faithful follow-on Worms World Party. Update the graphics, add a few classes, and add dynamic terrain features and water physics! Oh, but the curvy graphics make it hard to play precisely, classes feel more like a restriction than an exciting array of options, the water feels insignificant and flows like treacle, and when the terrain features aren't exploding, they just bounce around like balloons. Then, take away a bunch of the weapons and options, cut it down to 16 worms in a match, remove the ability to add custom content, simplify the missions into a glorified, tedious, unrewarding tutorial, and slow the whole thing to a snail's pace. Finally, replace the glorious ninja rope with a limp noodle.

Now, compared to something like Worms Reloaded, it's fine. Unfortunately, Worms Reloaded was an abortion of a game and fails miserably in comparison to the older titles. While Revolution does add a few features to try to distract from the fact that the last solid Worms game came out in 2001, the core gameplay just isn't good enough. Here's hoping we'll someday see a modern Worms title that actually builds up from the classics, instead of trying to start again.

Oh, but I nearly forgot! You get to put hats on your worms!
10/10 Best Game Ever

Oh sure, they may occasionally miss a shot, but it's all part of their endgame. You will lose. It doesn't help that the odds are firmly stacked against you at all times - your worms are often placed in the worst possible locations on the map, and the AI team always has more worms than you, often more than double. The Spooky levels are where it really becomes next to impossible. Looking for respite, I turned to the puzzles, but sorry, no rest there! reviewText:
I've played other worms games in the past with my friends, it was always a lot of fun and this game does not fail as a worms game. It's crazy and funny and reminds me a lot of Worms Amargedom. The controls answer very well, the weapons viriety is great, the sound is funny and the animations are awesome.

I do not recommend this game for a simple reason: it doesn't support anti-aliasing in AMD graphics card. This reason will not keep me away from this game, I'll surely play a lot more of it and I definitely recommend it if you have a Nvidia card or don't care about horrible aliasing, but I've seen lots of people upset about this and hence, cannot recommend it to everyone. And remember the game uses OpenGL, so, there's no way to use a AA injector (you can still use downsampling though).

Graphics: 4/10 - The lack of AA doesn't allow me to see the game's full potential here.
Sound: 7.9/10  - Although they are not outstanding quality-wise, the dialogue lines are extremely funny as so are the sound effects. The music is a little annoying, but it's a matter of taste.
Gameplay: 10/10 - You can blow worms, make them drown, punch them in the face, burn them, etc, all with flawless gameplay, big weapon variety, destructible environment and guaranteed laughs.
Environment: 9/10 - The environment is completely destructible, there's a nice map selection available and a map editor. The water available is also very useful and well made. The background animations also make the soldiers really look like worms, in previous worms games I always felt like they were giant mutant worms.

Final result: 7.7/10 - As I stated before I cannot recommend this game to everyone due to the lack of AA in AMD cards. There are lots of people who are really engaged into the graphics war" and if one of these people buy this game and have an AMD graphics card they'll be nothing short of frustrated. If you have a Nvidia card or just don't care for heavy aliasing this is an awesome title to get."

The multiplayer in this game is some of the best out there. Customizable game modes, a map creator, and lots of items.

However, this game isn't perfect. For one thing, the platforming is terrible. If you fall and take damage, costing you your turn, half the time the controls are to blame.

You could be on a tiny floating chunk of land just big enough to stand on and an AI worm can throw a grenade from across the map, ricochet it off walls and celings and get it to land perfectly on that worm's head without bouncing off. Not only are they unfair, but as you progress, they start to outnumber you more and more. I've gotten to the point where I've started with only 4 worms and the AI has 10. Unless you're the kind of person who enjoys games like Dark Souls, where the challenge is based on how unfair the AI is, I wouldn't touch the singleplayer with a 10 foot pole.

That aside though, this game is clearly meant to be played with friends anyways, and it's definitly worth the buy just for the multiplayer.

reviewText:
Worms Revolutions is the Best Release Yet

If you haven’t played Worms before, the concept is simple – Worms battle each other on 2D landscape. Players take turns launching weapons at the opposing team, blowing up Worms and destroying the landscape. There are several new gameplay elements, including physical objects, Worm Classes, great voice acting, that make this an amazing game.

The classes are one of the newer features and I believe it works and if you don't like it, you can just keep your formation of Worms made up of Soldiers. Worms are separated into Soldier, Heavy, Scientist, and Scout. The Soldier is the basic Worm, well rounded and the default starting Worm. Each of the other three classes has their own drawbacks and benefits. The Heavy Worm is heavy – the jetpack doesn’t last as long and he doesn’t move as fast. He also withstands more damage and deals more damage. The Scout Worm is at the opposite end of the spectrum, quick moving and weak. The Scientist Worm provides each Worm on the team with 5 health points every time his turn comes up. I like this update, it adds new strategies and fun.

The Single Player missions including both campaign play and puzzles is another area of refinement for the series. The entertaining and often hysterically funny actor, Matt Barry (The IT Crowd, The Mighty Boosh, and many other film and television credits), is your guide through these well designed missions. The first set of campaign missions includes 8 training missions, to introduce gameplay and the newer features.

The landscape editor allows you to create your own landscape for play. This tool is very easy to understand, so you can have your first landscape created within minutes.

Worm Revolution includes nicely rendered 2D landscapes on a 3D backdrop with various themes. Choose from three gameplay modes – single player missions with Matt Berry’s voice work, online multiplayer matches, or local versus matches against the computer or your friends.

Overall, this is a great game, whether you are a fan of the series of have never played it before, with simple concepts and fun quick action that can often result in hilarious outcomes. There is tons of replay value. This is one of those games that never gets old and the newer features add to the excitement.
